**Qu Feng Pill (Qu Feng Wan):**
Effects are the same as Hei Wan Zi.

**Ingredients:**
- *Gu Sui Bu* (drynaria), five liang
- *Chuan Wu* (Sichuan aconite), one liang
- *Chuan Xiong* (Sichuan lovage), one liang
- *Cao Wu* (wild aconite), two liang
- *Chuan Dang Gui* (Sichuan Chinese angelica), two liang
- *Niu Xi* (achyranthes), two liang
- *Mu Bie* (momordica seed), two liang
- *He Shou Wu* (fleeceflower root), four liang
- *Wu Jin* (black gold, i.e., *bai cao shuang* [soot]), four liang (some say *jing mo* [inkstick])

Grind into powder, form into pills with vinegar paste, each the size of a *wutong* seed. Take thirty pills per dose, on an empty stomach with salted water, or after meals with *jing jie* (schizonepeta) tea.

---

**Hei Hu Dan (Black Tiger Elixir):**
Treats numbness and paralysis of the hands and feet in men and women.

**Ingredients:**
- *Chuan Wu* (Sichuan aconite), one jin
- *Mu Bie* (momordica seed), one jin
- *Di Long* (earthworm), ten liang
- *Hei Dou* (black soybean), half a sheng
- *Wu Ling Zhi* (flying squirrel feces), two liang
- *Song Mo* (pine soot), two liang (stir-fried with vinegar)

Grind the first four ingredients into powder; grind *wu ling zhi* with vinegar and boil with wheat flour paste to form pills the size of *long yan* (longan). Take one or two pills per dose, chewed finely and swallowed with wine, or with peppermint tea, at any time.

---

**Shou Wu Wan (Fleeceflower Pill):**
Treats wind-induced damage and relaxes sinews.

**Ingredients:**
- *He Shou Wu* (fleeceflower root), ten jin (steamed with half a sheng of black soybeans until cooked)
- *Qian Niu Zi* (morning glory seed), ten liang (stir-fried)
- *Niu Xi* (achyranthes), twenty liang
- *Bo He* (peppermint), twenty liang
- *Chuan Wu* (Sichuan aconite), two liang
- *Qing Mu Xiang* (costus root), five liang
- *Zao Jiao* (Chinese honeylocust), two jin (one jin charred, one jin honey-fried)

Grind into powder, form into pills with wine paste, each the size of a *wutong* seed. Take thirty pills per dose, with scallion broth or peppermint tea, at any time.

---

**Yun Qi San (Qi-Regulating Powder):**
For severe injuries, administer this first to regulate qi before taking injury-specific remedies.

**Ingredients:**
- *Hui Xiang* (fennel), half a liang
- *Qing Pi* (unripe tangerine peel), half a liang
- *Hou Po* (magnolia bark, processed), half a liang
- *Bai Zhi* (angelica), half a liang
- *Wu Yao* (lindera), half a liang
- *Xing Ren* (apricot kernel, peeled and tips removed), half a liang
- *Chen Pi* (tangerine peel), one liang
- *Mai Nie* (fermented wheat), one liang
- *Qian Hu* (hogfennel), one liang
- *Jie Geng* (platycodon), one liang
- *Cang Zhu* (atractylodes), one liang
- *Fen Cao* (glycyrrhiza powder), one liang

Grind into powder. Take two *qian* per dose, decocted in one cup of water with ginger and jujube until reduced to eight parts, on an empty stomach.

---

**Si Wu Tang (Four Substances Decoction):**
For severe injuries with internal blood stasis.

**Ingredients:**
- *Bai Shao Yao* (white peony root)
- *Chuan Dang Gui* (Sichuan Chinese angelica)
- *Shu Di Huang* (prepared rehmannia)
- *Chuan Xiong* (Sichuan lovage)

Equal parts. Take three *qian* per dose, decocted in one and a half cups of water until reduced to seven parts, on an empty stomach while hot. One formula uses only *dang gui* and *da huang*.

---

**Qi Qi Tang (Seven Qi Decoction):**
- *Ban Xia* (pinellia), five liang
- *Ren Shen* (ginseng), one liang
- *Rou Gui* (cinnamon bark), one liang
- *Gan Cao* (licorice, honey-fried), one liang

Take three *qian* per dose, decocted in one cup of water with three slices of ginger until reduced to seven parts, before meals while hot.

---

**Wu Ji San (Five Accumulations Powder):**
Treats the five taxations and seven injuries. For head injuries, wind-induced chills, decoct two *qian* with ginger and add scallion, taken hot after meals.

**Ingredients:**
- *Cang Zhu* (atractylodes), twenty liang
- *Jie Geng* (platycodon), twenty liang
- *Zhi Qiao* (bitter orange), six liang
- *Chen Pi* (tangerine peel), six liang
- *Ma Huang* (ephedra, root and nodes removed), six liang
- *Shao Yao* (peony root), three liang
- *Bai Zhi* (angelica), three liang
- *Chuan Xiong* (Sichuan lovage), three liang
- *Chuan Dang Gui* (Sichuan Chinese angelica), three liang
- *Gan Cao* (licorice), three liang
- *Rou Gui* (cinnamon bark), three liang
- *Fu Ling* (poria), three liang
- *Ban Xia* (pinellia, soaked), three liang
- *Hou Po* (magnolia bark), four liang
- *Gan Jiang* (dried ginger), four liang

Except for *zhi qiao* and *rou gui*, finely chop the rest and stir-fry over low heat until discolored. Spread to cool, then mix with *zhi qiao* and *rou gui*. Take three *qian* per dose, decocted in one cup of water with three slices of ginger until reduced to half, taken hot.

---

**Da Cheng Tang (Major Success Decoction, also called Da Cheng Qi Tang):**
For extremely severe injuries with blocked urination and defecation. May add *mu tong* to the decoction. If still blocked, add *po xiao* (mirabilite) and wait until urination and defecation are restored before administering injury remedies. Injury remedies must not be decocted with wine, as this will worsen the blockage. Adjust dosage based on the patient’s constitution. Do not administer to pregnant women or children.

**Ingredients:**
- *Da Huang* (rhubarb), four liang
- *Zhi Qiao* (bitter orange), four liang
- *Chuan Mang Xiao* (Sichuan mirabilite), two liang
- *Gan Cao* (licorice), two liang
- *Chen Pi* (tangerine peel), two liang
- *Hong Hua* (safflower), two liang
- *Dang Gui* (Chinese angelica), two liang
- *Su Mu* (sappan wood), two liang
- *Mu Tong* (akebia), two liang
- *Hou Po* (magnolia bark), a small amount

Chop the ingredients. Take two *qian* per dose, decocted in one and a half cups of water until boiling once, strained and taken warm, at any time. This formula specifically treats severe injuries in men with unresolved blood stasis, abdominal distension, blocked urination and defecation, and upward attack on the heart and abdomen causing deadly distress. Administer urgently to purge blood stasis, then follow with injury remedies.

---

**Xiao Cheng Qi Tang (Minor Success Decoction):**
- *Da Huang* (rhubarb), four liang
- *Mang Xiao* (mirabilite), two *qian* (gradually added after decoction)
- *Zhi Shi* (immature bitter orange), two liang
- *Hou Po* (magnolia bark), eight liang

Effects are the same as *Da Cheng Tang*. This formula is milder and may be taken by women, girls, and children.

---

**Pai Feng Tang (Wind-Dispersing Decoction):**
Treats various wind-induced injuries.

**Ingredients:**
- *Bai Xian Pi* (dictamnus root bark), two liang
- *Bai Zhu* (white atractylodes), two liang
- *Shao Yao* (peony root), two liang
- *Rou Gui* (cinnamon bark, coarse skin removed), two liang
- *Chuan Xiong* (Sichuan lovage), two liang
- *Xing Ren* (apricot kernel, peeled and tips removed), two liang
- *Chuan Dang Gui* (Sichuan Chinese angelica, root head removed), two liang
- *Fang Feng* (saposhnikovia), two liang
- *Gan Cao* (licorice), two liang
- *Du Huo* (angelica pubescens), three liang
- *Ma Huang* (ephedra, root and nodes removed), three liang
- *Bai Fu Ling* (white poria), three liang

Take two *qian* per dose, decocted in one and a half cups of water with four slices of ginger until reduced to eight parts, at any time. Also recommended: *Xu Ming Tang* (Continuing Life Decoction) and *Xiao Feng San* (Wind-Dispersing Powder).

---

**Jie Gu Yao (Bone-Setting Remedies):**
- **Xia Ku Wu** (also called *e*, osprey): Burn the bones until carbonized, then take one ancient copper coin, quench seven times in vinegar, and grind into powder. Mix equal parts. After setting and binding the broken bone, take one *qian* of the powder with wine. Do not exceed the dosage. If the injury is below the waist, take on an empty stomach; if above, take after meals. This formula is highly effective.

- **Commonly Used Bone-Setting Remedy:** Scrape the skin off large *cao wu* (wild aconite) and grind into fine powder. Take half a *qian* per dose with warm wine. If no effect is felt, increase by two *fen* with medicinal wine.

- **Another Formula:** Grind *ru xiang* (frankincense) and *mo yao* (myrrh), two liang each, separately. Then grind *xue jie* (dragon’s blood), *zi ran tong* (pyrite), *wu ming yi* (unknown mineral), *mu bie* (momordica seed, boiled in vinegar), one liang each, and *di long* (earthworm), two liang, into powder. Form into pills with honey the size of *long yan* (longan). Chew thoroughly and swallow with hot wine. Afterward, chew raw scallion to counteract.

---

**Zhi Zhen San (True Restoration Powder, also called Duo Ming San [Life-Saving Powder]):**
Treats traumatic injuries, skull fractures, wind-induced head pain, and opisthotonus.

**For Severe Traumatic Injuries:**
First, administer **Major Qi-Coordinating Decoction (Da Cheng Qi Tang)**, **Minor Qi-Coordinating Decoction (Xiao Cheng Qi Tang)**, or **Four Substances Decoction (Si Wu Tang)** to unblock the bowels and bladder and expel stagnant blood. For women, use **Yin-Red Decoction (Yin Hong Tang)** to achieve the same effect.

Second, administer **Yellow Powder (Huang Mo Yao)**, mixed with warm wine, without regard to timing. If the injury is in the upper body, take after meals; if in the lower body, take on an empty stomach; if the entire body aches, take before bed.

Third, administer **White Powder (Bai Mo Yao)**, mixed with hot wine, following the same method as the Yellow Powder. It also treats all blood disorders in women postpartum.

Fourth, administer **Black Pill (Wu Wan Zi)**.

Fifth, administer **Red Pill (Hong Wan Zi)**.

Sixth, administer **Hemp Pill (Ma Wan Zi)**, swallowed with warm wine. For women, use mugwort-vinegar decoction. Pregnant women must not take this.

Seventh, administer **Blood-Quickening Elixir (Huo Xue Dan)**, **Chinese Angelica Powder (Dang Gui San)**, and **Frankincense Powder (Ru Xiang San)**. The two powders are detailed in previous formulas; both are taken with wine, without regard to timing, following the same method as the Yellow and White Powders. For **Frankincense Powder**, the *Mountain Spring Formula* adds six additional ingredients: *baiyangpi* (white poplar bark, 1 *jin*), raw *jiezi* (mustard seeds, 10 pieces), *zelan* (bugleweed, 1 *jin*), *tanxiang* (sandalwood, 6 *liang*), *chenxiang* (aloeswood, 2 *liang*), and *chuanxiong* (Sichuan lovage, 1 *jin*). The remaining formulas are listed below.

**Major Qi-Coordinating Decoction**, **Minor Qi-Coordinating Decoction**, and **Four Substances Decoction** are all found in previous formulas.

---

**Yellow Powder (Huang Mo Yao)**
Treats falls, blows, and traumatic injuries where skin and flesh are torn, sinews and muscles severed, stagnant blood congested, abscesses festered, and pain is extreme. Also treats injuries from overexertion, pain in the shoulders, back, and limbs, post-injury wind invasion causing numbness and weakness in the hands and feet, inability to move, sinew and bone deformities, and contractures. It excels at reconnecting sinews and setting bones. Regular use quickens blood, reduces swelling, and restores strength.

*Chuanwu* (prepared Sichuan aconite), *caowu* (wild aconite, vinegar-boiled), *fengxiang* (resin of sweetgum, separately ground, each 3 *jin*); *danggui* (Chinese angelica, root tips removed, wine-soaked overnight, shade-dried), *chishaoyao* (red peony, each ½ *liang*); *chuanduhuo* (Sichuan pubescent angelica, root tips removed), *chuanxiong* (Sichuan lovage, water-soaked seven times), *xixin* (asarum, roots and leaves removed, thoroughly washed), *xiangbaizhi* (fragrant angelica), *shangui* (cassia bark, coarse skin removed), *baijiang* (white ginger, wrapped in dough and baked), *huangjiang* (yellow ginger, wrapped in paper and baked), *wujiapi* (acanthopanax bark, thoroughly washed, bones removed), *jiegeng* (platycodon, root tips removed), *suibu* (drynaria, hairs removed, stir-fried), *cangzhu* (atractylodes, vinegar-boiled seven times), *heshouwu* (fleeceflower root, black bean-wine boiled seven times), *niuxi* (achyranthes, wine-soaked seven days, dried, each 2 *jin*); *zhimu* (anemarrhena, ½ *jin*); *moyao* (myrrh, ½ *jin*).

Grind the above into fine powder. Take 2 *qian* per dose, mixed with salted wine. If the injury is in the upper body, take after meals; if in the lower body, take on an empty stomach. For whole-body injuries, take before bed. Pregnant women must not take this.

---

**White Powder (Bai Mo Yao)**
Treats traumatic injuries with torn skin and flesh, severed sinews and bones, congested stagnant blood, persistent swelling, or abscess formation, with extreme pain. Also treats post-injury wind invasion causing numbness and weakness in the hands and feet, inability to move, sinew and bone deformities, and contractures, as well as overexertion injuries with pain in the shoulders, back, and limbs. This formula excels at reconnecting sinews and setting bones, yielding rapid results. It also treats all blood disorders in women postpartum.

*Jiegeng* (platycodon, roots and leaves removed), *baizhi* (angelica), *gancao* (licorice, roasted, each 10 *liang*); *chuanxiong* (Sichuan lovage, water-soaked seven times), *shangui* (cassia bark, coarse skin removed), *xixin* (asarum, roots removed, each ½ *jin*); *chuanwu* (prepared Sichuan aconite), *duanxu* (dipsacus, rice-water soaked), *niuxi* (achyranthes, roots removed, wine-soaked overnight), *danggui* (Chinese angelica), *xiangfuz* (cyperus, stir-fried, each 6 *liang*); *huajiao* (Sichuan pepper, seeds and closed pods removed, 5 *liang*); *chishaoyao* (red peony, wine-soaked overnight), *zelanye* (bugleweed leaves, branches removed, each 9 *liang*); *baiyangpi* (white poplar bark, 12 *liang*, rice-water soaked overnight).

Grind into fine powder. Take 2 *qian* per dose, mixed with wine. Administration follows the same method as above. It treats all blood and wind disorders in women.

---

**Black Pill (Wu Wan Zi)**
Treats traumatic injuries with broken bones and severed sinews, stagnant blood that will not disperse, and all wind disorders causing sinew atrophy, weakness, hemiplegia, limb flaccidity, and various wind-related injuries. Also treats blood disorders in women, postpartum stagnant blood that fails to disperse and floods the limbs, causing facial and limb swelling. Pregnant women must not take this.

*Chixiaodou* (adzuki beans, stir-fried), *bailian* (ampelopsis), *xixin* (asarum, roots removed), *chishaoyao* (red peony), *heshouwu* (fleeceflower root, vinegar-boiled), *baiji* (bletilla, baked), *caowu* (wild aconite, vinegar-boiled seven times), *shangui* (cassia bark, coarse skin removed), *chuanxiong* (Sichuan lovage), *nanxing* (arisaema, wheat-bran wrapped and baked), *danggui* (Chinese angelica, wine-soaked overnight), *chuanniuxi* (Sichuan achyranthes, roots removed, wine-soaked overnight), *baicaoshuang* (soot from burned grasses), *gusuibu* (drynaria, hairs removed, stir-fried), *taitaiawuyao* (lindera, black bean-wine boiled then dried, each 1½ *liang*).

Grind into fine powder, mix with wine-cooked wheat-flour paste, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take 50 pills per dose, with scallion-cooked wine or scallion tea.

---

**Red Pill (Hong Wan Zi)**
Treats traumatic injuries with broken bones and severed sinews, pain, numbness, and cold, internal and external damage, stagnant blood retention, external swelling with internal pain, limb and joint soreness, and all types of injuries, regardless of duration. Regular use strengthens sinews, consolidates bones, nourishes blood, and restores strength, with miraculous effects beyond description. Pregnant women must not take this.

*Niuxi* (achyranthes, wine-soaked overnight), *chuanwu* (prepared Sichuan aconite), *nanxing* (arisaema, vinegar-boiled three times), *xixin* (asarum, roots and leaves removed, thoroughly washed), *heshouwu* (fleeceflower root, water-boiled until soft), *jiegeng* (platycodon, root tips removed), *shangui* (cassia bark, coarse skin removed), *danggui* (Chinese angelica), *bailian* (ampelopsis), *chishaoyao* (red peony), *moyao* (myrrh, separately ground), *gusuibu* (drynaria, hairs removed), *qianghuo* (notopterygium, root tips removed), *chixiaodou* (adzuki beans, unroasted), *zirantong* (pyrite, calcined, vinegar-quenched seven times, separately ground).

Except for the separately ground ingredients, stir-fry the rest together, grind into powder, and mix with wine-cooked wheat-flour paste to form pills. Take 50 pills per dose, adjusting timing based on the location of the injury.

**Hempseed Pills**
For treating traumatic fractures and injuries with broken skin and exposed bone, shattered limbs, necrotic flesh, and excruciating pain—where the patient cries out day and night, unresponsive to all treatments. Also for long-standing limb injuries with displaced sinews and bones, rendering movement impossible; post-injury afflictions of wind-dampness causing contracture of joints and eventual paralysis; overstrain injuries to sinews and bones with shoulder and back pain; weakness and debility of the limbs; and lack of strength in movement. Regular use strengthens sinews and bones, activates the meridians, and generates qi and blood. Also treats women’s blood and qi disorders. *Contraindicated for pregnant women.*

**Ingredients:**
*Chuandanggui* (Chinese angelica), *jiegeng* (platycodon, called *buluofu*), *niuxi* (achyranthes, not wine-steeped), each ½ tael; *gusuibu* (drynaria, hairs removed) 2 taels; *chuanxiong* (ligusticum), *baicaoshuang* (soot from burned grasses), *caowu* (wild aconite, steeped in *zhoushanfan* ash water) each 1 catty; *mubiezi* (momordica, oil and shell removed), *chishaoyao* (red peony) each ½ catty; *jinmaogouji* (cibotium, tail removed); *wudou* (black soybeans) 1 *sheng*, wine-boiled and dried; *chuanwu* (Sichuan aconite, not fired, sliced, vinegar-boiled).

Grind into powder, mix with wine-cooked wheat-flour paste to form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take 50 pills per dose with warm wine; for women, take with mugwort-vinegar decoction.

---

**Life-Activating Elixir**
For treating falls, contusions, and traumatic injuries with broken bones and severed sinews, painful swelling, and stagnant blood flooding the limbs, causing restlessness and distress. Also for deep abscesses, carbuncles, necrotic flesh, and all wind disorders—hemiplegia, paralysis, numbness of the limbs; and women’s blood-wind agitation. All such conditions may be treated with this formula.

Take half a pill per dose, ground in ash-free wine, gently simmered three to five times, and taken warm at any time, without restriction on quantity. Store the pills in a gauze bag in a quiet place; they remain potent indefinitely and may be kept for emergencies. *Contraindicated for pregnant women.*

**Ingredients:**
*Jingjie* (schizonepeta) 2½ taels; *caowu* (wild aconite, wine-boiled), *chuanwu* (Sichuan aconite, blast-fried) each 3 taels; *fengxiang* (liquidambar, separately ground), *tanxiang* (sandalwood, not fired), *jiangzhenjie* (dalbergia heartwood), *ruxiang* (frankincense, separately ground), *moyao* (myrrh, separately ground) each 1 tael; *shanggui* (cassia bark, coarse skin removed), *danggui* (Chinese angelica, wine-steeped briefly), *chuanqianghuo* (Sichuan notopterygium, root tips removed), *baiji* (bletilla, wrapped in flour and baked, sun-dried), *dilong* (earthworm, soil removed), *shexiang* (musk, separately ground), *suibu* (drynaria, hairs removed, stir-fried), *chuanniuxi* (Sichuan achyranthes, wine-steeped briefly), *xixin* (asarum, stems removed), *huasangmu* (mulberry wood, burned to ash), *baizhi* (angelica, undamaged), *chishaoyao* (red peony, wine-steeped), *chuanqianniu* (morning glory, stir-fried with lime), *tianli* (horse chestnut), *wudou* (black soybeans, stir-fried with glutinous rice flour until yellow), *chuanxiong* (ligusticum, washed three times in hot water), *nanxing* (arisaema, stir-fried with lime until yellow), *zirantong* (pyrite, calcined, wine-quenched, separately ground), *cangzhu* (atractylodes, soaked in rice water—spring 5 days, summer 3, autumn 7, winter 10—then stir-fried dry) each ½ tael; *diqing* (pitch, separately ground) 1½ *qian*; *wulingzhi* (trogopterus dung, 1½ taels, ground with rush pith); *mubie* (momordica, 20 seeds, oil and shell removed).

Grind into fine powder, mix with wine-cooked wheat-flour paste to form pills the size of bullets. Pound in a mortar over thirty times to form a solid mass. Weigh out one tael and divide into three pills. When the pills are formed, divide them into three portions: one portion air-dried, one sun-dried for half a day, and one baked for half a day. Then recombine the three portions, blending yin and yang, until the medicinal qi is balanced. Brush off any dust and coat the pills with black lacquer.

After washing the injury, apply the *Immortal’s Corrective Powder* (details follow). For severe injuries, first wash, then apply *Black Dragon Plaster*. The washing formula is as above. Another version includes *Shanquan* washing formula.

**Washing Formula:**
*Mushuzhai* (euonymus), *shinanye* (photinia leaves), *baizhi* (angelica), *baiyangpi* (poplar bark), *shengcong* (fresh scallions), *heshouwu* (fleeceflower), *tudanggui* (local angelica), *jingjie* (schizonepeta), *gaoben* (ligusticum), *shaoyao* (peony). Use any quantity, decoct in water, and when warm, wash the injured area until clean. Pat the wound dry with silk.

---

**Black Dragon Plaster**
For treating traumatic injuries with broken bones, severed sinews, and dislocated joints. Usage is detailed in the *Black Dragon Powder* formula above. First wash, manipulate, and set the injury, then apply the plaster and bind it. The powder may also be sprinkled directly onto the wound.

**Ingredients:**
*Baijiangcan* (silkworm, silk and mouthparts removed, stir-fried) 6 taels; *chixiaodou* (adzuki beans) 6 taels; *chuanniuxi* (Sichuan achyranthes, root tips removed) 6 taels; *shanggui* (cassia bark, skin removed), *jiegeng* (platycodon), *baiji* (bletilla, raw, sliced, air-dried), *shanpipa* (eriobotrya leaves, raw, sliced, air-dried) each 1 catty; *baicaoshuang* (soot), *dangguiwei* (angelica tail), *suibu* (drynaria, hairs removed, stir-fried) each ½ catty; *beixixin* (northern asarum, stems removed) ½ catty; *baizhi* (angelica), *nanxing* (arisaema, baked), *chishaoyao* (red peony), *heshouwu* (fleeceflower), *bailian* (ampelopsis) each 10 taels; *zhimu* (anemarrhena), *caowu* (wild aconite, ginger-juice boiled) each 3 taels.

**Emergency Immortal Formulas, Scroll Eight**
**Methods for Treating Boils**

At the onset of a *ding* boil, most people remain unaware. It may arise on the head, face, hands, feet, abdomen, flanks, waist, or legs—no fixed location. Within one or two days, it invariably induces malarial-like chills and fever, headache, and unbearable body pain, its ache distinct from ordinary afflictions. One must thoroughly examine the body to identify the sore. If a small sore appears, differing slightly from common lesions, it is a *ding* boil.

These boils arise from various causes, and their forms likewise differ:
- **Pig boil**: Round and small, with oil in the sore’s opening.
- **Sheep boil**: Elongated and white.
- **Ox boil**: Round and small, with no oil in the sore’s opening.
- **Dog boil**: Elongated or pointed, red.
- **Donkey/horse boil**: Triangular in shape, with a black dot at the apex and red roots.

Note that these boils are not solely caused by the toxins of pigs, oxen, dogs, sheep, donkeys, or horses. Drinking stagnant, unclean water may produce a **water boil**; consuming tofu contaminated with human sweat may produce a **tofu boil**. There are also **qi boils** and **ghost boils**, whose forms vary, yet their treatment methods remain uniform.

**Slow-progressing sore coloration**:
- Day 1: Sore apex appears slightly white.
- Day 2: Color deepens to white.
- Day 3: Hue turns faint purple.
- Day 4: True purple appears.

**Rapid-progressing sore coloration**:
- Day 5: Faint green, slightly taut.
- Day 6: Deep green, greatly taut.
- Day 7: Black, resembling a fish’s navel or a scald—this is the most critical stage.

**Auspicious signs in boil symptoms**:
If, alongside the primary boil, another small sore appears elsewhere on the body, this is termed "having an echo." Prick it with a needle to protect the surrounding area. If the boil’s periphery reddens and swells, with multiple sores emerging (called "scattered stars"), yet appetite remains normal, with headache, fever, and warm hands and feet, the condition is favorable.

**Ominous signs in boil symptoms**:
If no sore appears elsewhere, failing to protect the area, and the boil’s periphery lacks redness or swelling, the prognosis is poor. For **internal boils**, symptoms include intense thirst, inability to eat, dizziness, blurred vision, inability to rise or move in bed, fixed white of the eye, cyanotic lips and tongue, and severe abdominal pain. **Five-center swelling**, cold hands and feet, coarse breathing, and pulselessness also indicate criticality.

**Peach-Red Powder** treats all *ding* boils. Even if dire symptoms manifest and all six pulses cease, indicating death, this formula can still govern the condition.
*Toad venom*; *arsenic* (small amount); *cicada slough* (feet and wings removed); *blister beetle* (feet and wings removed), 3 each; *centipede head*, 1; *national cinnabar*, 5 qian; *air-slaked lime*, 1 liang (baked in a sand pot with a tile and charcoal for one hour, then removed).

Process each ingredient, grind together into an extremely fine powder, and mix with the mucus from the inner skin of scallion white using a fingernail.

First, pierce the sore’s opening with a *he*-leaf needle to a depth of half an inch. All *ding* boils have red-threaded paths; insert the needle obliquely along these threads. If the sore is above the chest, angle the needle downward; if below, angle upward. Since boil toxins tend toward the heart, needle insertion should follow the toxin’s course. After withdrawing the needle, allow foul blood to drain completely. Then place a grain of toad venom the size of a wheat kernel into the sore’s opening, using the needle to push it deep inside. Apply the scallion-mixed powder to the sore’s opening—avoid healthy flesh. Soak 20–30 layers of paper in cold water, place over the medicine, and seal the sore firmly. If sealed in the early morning, by evening, if the sore feels hot, remove the paper, wash away the residue, and apply **Jade-Red Powder** to the sore’s opening. The sore will fester and ache for several days; continue applying Jade-Red Powder and washing daily with scallion decoction.

Though *ding* boils may appear perilous, pricking the sore, inserting toad venom, and sealing it with Peach-Red Powder can ensure recovery. If the sore festers and pain becomes unbearable, do not worry—this is not the boil’s toxicity harming the body but the toad venom corroding the boil’s toxins, hence the pain. Gather **cotton rose leaves** (mulberry leaves may substitute), grind, and apply around the sore to disperse blood and prevent congestion. Change the medicine day and night, washing the sore before each application. The sore will heal swiftly.

When a *ding* boil first erupts, it invariably causes chills, fever, and body pain—this indicates toxic *qi* at the surface, requiring sweating to resolve. **Naturally Boiling Decoction** governs this.
For the elderly, weak, or pregnant, sweating and purging are inadvisable; use Peach-Red Powder to draw out toxins.

**Naturally Boiling Decoction**
*Alum*, 5 qian; *indigo*, 3 qian; *tomb-side sun-dried lime*, 3 qian.

Grind the above ingredients into a fine powder, ensuring no grit remains, then blend thoroughly. For each dose, take three *qian*, mix with half a bowl of well-flower water, and stir vigorously with a willow twig a hundred times until even. Drink in one draught. Cover with thick clothing for a good while, then take a hot decoction of scallion and fermented soybeans with a little vinegar to reinforce the medicine’s power, inducing sweating to resolve the condition.

If the *ding* boil was initially unnoticed and no sweating was induced by the previous method, after several days the chills, fever, and body pain will subside, but the toxic *qi* will have turned inward. Purgative medicine must then be used to discharge the internal toxins, for which **Realgar Pill** governs.

**Realgar Pill**
*Realgar* and *curcuma* (tumeric), 5 *qian* each; *croton seed*, half a *qian* (remove kernels and shells, lightly defat).
One formula adds a pinch of *arsenic* (no more), boiled in clear oil for half a day, then dried and added to the medicine.
Another adds seven *blister beetles* (remove wings and feet, stir-fry with glutinous rice until discolored, discard the rice).
Yet another adds 3 *qian* of *refined mirabilite* to treat swollen and painful throat, throat blockage, and similar conditions.

Grind each into a fine powder, form into pills with wheat-flour paste the size of mung beans. Take seven pills with cold tea, adjusting the dose to induce bowel movement. If no movement occurs, take again.

**Jade-Red Powder**
*Calcitum* (calcined), 1 *liang*; *calomel* and *minium*, a small amount each.
Grind into a fine powder and sprinkle on the sore, washing and reapplying twice day and night.

Since toad venom ointment and Peach-Red Powder are both potent medicines, they cause sore pain. Jade-Red Powder neutralizes their toxicity, while the two medicines disperse blood—thus the sore will naturally heal.

If the above toad venom, Peach-Red Powder, or similar medicines cannot be immediately identified, Li Shi’an’s unified treatment method may be used, with even swifter efficacy.

**Li Shi’an’s Treatment Method**
**Chinese Angelica Powder**
*Chinese angelica tail*, 2 *liang*; *Sichuan lovage*, *dried kudzu*, *schizonepeta spike*, *lindera*, *angelica*, *Sichuan angelica*, *red peony*, *cimicifuga*, 1 *liang* each; *notopterygium*, *licorice*, *siler* (remove nodes), *bitter orange*, half a *liang* each; *safflower* and *sappan wood*, 2.5 *qian* each.
For sore pain, add 5 *qian* each of *frankincense*, *myrrh*, and *angelica*.
For persistent fever, add a small amount of *bamboo shavings* and *gardenia*.
For constipation, add 1 *liang* of *bitter orange*.
For restlessness, add ten *rush piths* and one piece of *bamboo shavings*.
For thirst, add 1 *liang* of *trichosanthes root*.
For swelling, add half a *liang* each of *licorice node* and *dalbergia node*.
For dizziness, add *Sichuan lovage*, *angelica*, *schizonepeta*, and *siler*.
For thirst with urinary blockage, add 1 *liang* of *talcum*.

Crush the ingredients, take 5 *qian* per dose, decoct with ten-odd *rush piths* and ten black soybeans in one and a half cups of water until reduced to eight parts. For upper-body sores, take after meals; for lower-body sores, take before meals. Administer repeatedly for efficacy.

If a *ding* boil goes unnoticed at first and no sweating is induced by the previous method, after several days the external symptoms will subside, but swelling may arise in the abdomen, flanks, chest, or armpits—this indicates the toxic *qi* has turned inward, requiring **Thunderbolt Fire** treatment.

If external symptoms persist after taking Chinese Angelica Powder, apply Thunderbolt Fire without delay.

**Thunderbolt Fire Method**
Heat a goose-egg-sized cobblestone until red-hot. Place a bamboo chair inside a large tub, with a ladle beneath the chair. Have the patient sit naked on the chair. Mix *schizonepeta* powder with sour rice vinegar in a vessel, then place the red-hot stone in the ladle and pour the *schizonepeta*-vinegar mixture over it. Avoid excessive heat to prevent scalding. If the fire weakens before sweating occurs, add more heat and pour again. Cover the tub’s opening with a quilt, and drape another over the patient’s head, leaving only the mouth and nose exposed. Ensure sweat emerges over the entire body, including the head and face—then the illness will resolve. This method is exceptionally effective.

For the elderly, weak, or pregnant—who should not undergo sweating or purging—pierce the sore, apply **Sea Horse Toxin-Drawing Powder** to the wound, and administer a wine-decocted *xanthium* drink.

If the toxin has turned inward and Thunderbolt Fire is used, the patient need not enter the tub. Instead, use a small bucket: place the ladle with the red-hot stone inside, pour vinegar over it, and have the patient lean over the bucket, covering the swollen area. Seal with quilts to prevent steam from escaping. After a while, sweat will emerge from the swollen area. If sweating is insufficient, add more heat and pour again, ensuring the swollen area sweats thoroughly—full-body sweating is unnecessary.

If the sore is between the flanks and the toxin threatens to rush toward the heart, this is a critical condition. Immediately apply three to five moxa cones to the sore’s tip, then bleed slightly before and after the moxa site. Blisters forming around the moxa wound are auspicious; their absence is ominous.

For sores in soft or inaccessible areas where needling or moxibustion is impractical, use the **Pine Needle Cutting Method** to sever the red-thread path. If the sore is between the hips and the toxin threatens the kidneys, use pine needles to sever the red-thread path at its terminus in the hips, drawing blood. For sores on the head or face, sever the thread path at the nape or wherever it terminates, drawing blood. If the red-thread path is not visible, infer its course and use pine needles to sever it.

The Pine Needle Method is employed when the red-thread path is invisible and no clear point of intervention exists. Apply it to soft areas beneath the jaw, armpits, or hips to sever the toxic *qi* and prevent it from attacking the heart or kidneys.

chunks.original_text: 松针法 取向北松枝上叶极硬者，顿齐作一束，扎令极紧，缓缓以意消详毒气所经行虚软处针之，须令出血。 针时先用酒润下针处，针必小痛，令病人稍忍。 仍用雄黄麝香为末，温酒调一二服与之，服之方下针。 若表证皆罢，毒气入裹者，用前雄黄丸主之。 若手足厥玲，六脉俱绝者，此乃毒气已深，气血为毒气所并，不能流通，是以体玲而不现，必须用木香流气饮，连进数服，气血流通，则脉自回矣。 然后依法治之，万无一失。 海马拔毒散，治疔疮大效，兼治诸恶疮发背。 海马一只，炙 穿山甲黄土炒 水银 朱砂各二钱 雄黄三钱 轻粉一钱 脑子 麝香各少许 右件除水银外，各研为末打合，入水银再研至无星。 针破疮口，点药入内，一日一点，神效。 夫内疔之证与外疼之证并同，亦发寒热，头疼体痛，但疮形不现，过数日胸背腹胁头面手足间，或有一处肿起，即内疔所发之处，急用霹雳火如前，不护场汗法，於肿处出汗。 若身体寒热，虽未有肿起，但腹痛甚者，便须作内疔证，用后法治之，不可缓也。 用蟾酥一粒，病势重者用二粒，置病人舌上噙化。 化后良久，用井花水灌漱，却用雄黄丸七丸，冷茶清吞下，得脏腑利数行，其病应手而愈。 凡治内疔，蟾酥可於取时，用桑叶小钱大，入蟾酥揉和得所，丸如念珠大，阴乾。 急救仙方卷之八卷 #1辨：疑为『 办」之讹。

**Pine Needle Method**

Select the hardest needles from the north-facing branches of a pine tree, bundle them tightly together, and align them evenly. Carefully determine the path of the toxic *qi* and apply the needles to the soft, vulnerable areas, ensuring that blood is drawn. Before needling, moisten the area with wine; the patient may experience slight pain, which they should endure briefly. Administer one or two doses of realgar and musk powder mixed with warm wine before needling.

If the exterior symptoms have resolved but the toxic *qi* has turned inward, use the aforementioned **Realgar Pill** to treat it. If the limbs are cold and the six pulses have all ceased, this indicates that the toxic *qi* has penetrated deeply, overwhelming the *qi* and blood and obstructing their flow—hence the cold body and imperceptible pulse. In such cases, administer the **Wood Fragrance Qi-Flowing Decoction** in several consecutive doses to restore the circulation of *qi* and blood, after which the pulse will naturally return. Then proceed with the appropriate treatment; success is certain.

The **Sea Horse Toxin-Extracting Powder** is highly effective for treating clove sores and also addresses all types of malignant sores and carbuncles on the back. Its ingredients are:
- One sea horse (roasted)
- Two *qian* each of pangolin scales (stir-fried with yellow earth), mercury, and cinnabar
- Three *qian* of realgar
- One *qian* of calomel
- Small amounts of borneol and musk

Grind all ingredients except mercury into powder, then incorporate the mercury and grind until no specks remain. Pierce the sore and apply the powder inside once daily; its efficacy is divine.

The symptoms of internal clove sores resemble those of external hemorrhoids, including chills, fever, headache, and body aches. However, no visible sore appears. After several days, swelling may arise in one area of the chest, back, abdomen, flanks, head, face, hands, or feet—this marks the site of the internal clove sore. Immediately apply the **Thunderbolt Fire** method as before, inducing sweat at the swollen area without protecting the surrounding skin. If the body experiences chills and fever, even without swelling, but severe abdominal pain is present, treat it as an internal clove sore using the following method without delay.

Place one **toad venom** pellet on the patient’s tongue (use two if the condition is severe) and allow it to dissolve. After some time, rinse the mouth with fresh well water, then administer seven **Realgar Pills** with cold tea. Once the bowels move several times, the illness will resolve immediately.

When preparing toad venom for treating internal clove sores, take a mulberry leaf the size of a small coin, mix it with the venom, and knead until well combined. Form the mixture into beads the size of prayer beads and dry them in the shade.

*Emergency Immortal Remedies*, Scroll Eight
*(Note: The character 辨 appears to be a misprint for 办.)*

chunks.original_text: 急救仙方卷之九 秘传五痔品 原痔者，贫富男女皆有之。 富者，酒色财气； 贫者，担轻负重，饥露早行。 皆心肝二血，喜则伤心，怒则伤肝，喜怒无常，风血侵於大肠，到谷道无出路，结积成块，出血生乳，各有形相。 妇人因经后伤冷，月事伤风，余血在心经，血乃流入於大肠。 小儿因利后，或母腹中受热也。 治方于后。 水澄膏护肉。 郁金　白友各一两，一方加黄连 右二味为细末，候内痔登厕翻出在外，用温汤洗净，不须坐入，即侧外床沿上，用新水和蜜，调令稀稠，用篦挑药，轻手涂谷道四边好肉上，只留痔头在外，用薄纸圆转盖药上，仍用笔蘸温水涂纸上。 纸以护水澄膏，不令四散耳。 才觉药乾，又用温水润之，后用枯药： 好白矾四两　生信石二钱半　朱砂一钱，生研，十分细为妙 右各研为细末，先用砒在建盏中，次用白矾末盖之，用火煅令姻断，其砒尽随姻去，止借砒气於矾中耳。 用矾为细末，十分细可也。 看痔头大小，用矾末在掌上，入生朱砂少许，以唾调稀，用篦头涂痔上周遍。 一日三上，须子细看痔头颜色焦黑为妙。 至夜有黄水出，切勿他疑，水尽为妙，至中夜上药一遍，来日依然上药三次，有小痛不妨。 换药时以碗盛新水或温汤，在痔边用笔一管轻洗刷痔上，去旧药，上新药，仍用护药。 此药只是借砒信，又有朱砂少解砒毒。 次用荆芥汤洗之，三两日之后，黄水出将尽，却於药中增朱砂臧白矾，则药边缓矣。 三两日方可增臧，渐渐取之，庶不惊人。 全在用药人看痔头转色，增臧厚薄傅药，方是治法。 刑芥汤 右用刻芥锉，水三碗煎，常常煎下。 如洗痔了，依然倾入瓶内，火煨之，可用三五次。 润肠丸 大黄湿纸包煨，锉　枳壳去禳　当归蜜炼 右三味等分，为末蜜丸。 每服二十丸或三十丸，汤下，量脏腑虚实多寡服之。 绿为已用枯药后，痔头将欲焦枯，粪门迫急，恐大便坚难下，所以预服此，令脏腑稀滑耳。 龙石散 龙骨煅，去火毒　香白芷　好黄丹　软石膏煅，去火毒 右等分，为极细末，候痔头落尽，以此药掺，收敛疮口。 预先备好血碣末，止血或敛疮口，仓卒要用耳。 导赤散 生地黄二两　黄芩三两 右锉，每服三钱，水一盏，煎六七分，温服。 用药之后，小便恐赤涩，即服之，加滑石、甘草、灯心。 双金散 黄连　郁金 右二味等分，为末极细，用蜜水调傅痔头上。 虚人已用枯药，上忽有些疼痛用此。 其止一方，只用脑子末傅亦可。 内补散，此药调理气血，排脓生肌，候痔疮将欲收敛，即服此。 所谓肠头直候，疮口安好，血气中和，自然收入。 人参　黄耆　当归各二两　桔梗　芎藭　厚朴　官桂　防风　白芷　甘草各一两 右十味各等分，为细末，木香汤温酒亦可，日二三服。 国老汤 甘草煎汤，常常要煎，下熏洗痔疮。 盖甘草自是痔药，又解砒毒，若疮收敛，其痒异常，尤要此药浇洗，温热随意。 催痔，治痔虽硬只是不脱，用此药催自落。 百草霜二钱　白姜末一钱　川乌头 右为细末，以井水调稀，以笔点痔上，良久立脱。 熨法 凡医痔，用枯痔药，后急大小便间好肉疼如针刺，及痛上肾根，令人将衣物火上烘之令热，熨痛处三五次，其痛立止。 水澄膏，盖虑痔根毒水流污好肉生疮，故用药涂油单纸，护内周遍，下不用连纸，贴定可也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Emergency Immortal Remedies, Scroll Nine: Secret Transmission on the Five Types of Hemorrhoids**

**Origins of Hemorrhoids**
Hemorrhoids afflict both rich and poor, men and women alike.
Among the wealthy, they arise from excess in wine, lust, wealth, and temper;
among the poor, from bearing heavy burdens, hunger, exposure, and early travel.
In all cases, they stem from the blood of the heart and liver.
Joy injures the heart; anger injures the liver.
When joy and anger are unregulated, wind and blood invade the large intestine,
becoming trapped at the anus with no outlet.
They congeal into masses, causing bleeding and prolapse, each with its own form.
In women, they may follow menstrual chill or wind-induced menstrual disorders,
leaving residual blood in the heart meridian that flows into the large intestine.
In children, they may arise after diarrhea or from heat contracted in the womb.
Treatment methods follow below.

**Water-Settled Paste to Protect Healthy Tissue**
*Grind the following into fine powder:*
- Turmeric (1 tael)
- White clay (1 tael)
*(One formula adds coptis.)*

When internal hemorrhoids prolapse during defecation, wash the area with warm water.
Do not sit; instead, lie on the edge of the bed.
Mix the powder with fresh water and honey to a thin consistency.
Using a small spatula, gently apply the paste to the healthy tissue around the anus,
leaving only the hemorrhoid head exposed.
Cover with a thin paper circle, then brush the paper with warm water
to prevent the paste from scattering.
When the paste dries, remoisten it with warm water.

**Caustic Paste (for Shrinking Hemorrhoids)**
*Grind each separately into fine powder:*
- Good-quality alum (4 taels)
- Raw arsenic (2.5 candareens)
- Cinnabar (1 candareen, raw and finely ground)

First place the arsenic in a Jian ware bowl, then cover with alum powder.
Heat over fire until smoke ceases, allowing the arsenic to vaporize entirely,
leaving only its *qi* infused in the alum.
Grind the alum into an extremely fine powder.
Assess the size of the hemorrhoid head:
place alum powder in the palm, add a pinch of cinnabar,
and mix with saliva to a thin consistency.
Apply to the entire hemorrhoid head with a spatula, three times daily.
Observe closely: when the hemorrhoid turns charred black, the treatment is effective.
By night, yellow fluid will discharge—do not be alarmed, for its complete drainage is ideal.
Apply the paste once more at midnight, then resume three applications the next day.
Mild pain is normal.
When changing the paste, fill a bowl with fresh or warm water,
and gently wash the hemorrhoid with a brush to remove old paste before applying new.
Continue using the protective paste.

**Adjustments to the Caustic Paste**
This paste relies on arsenic’s potency, tempered by cinnabar to mitigate its toxicity.
After two or three days, when the yellow fluid nears exhaustion,
gradually increase the proportion of cinnabar and reduce the alum
to soften the paste’s edge.
Adjustments should be made every two or three days, proceeding gradually to avoid alarming the patient.
The practitioner must observe the hemorrhoid’s color changes
and modulate the thickness of the paste accordingly—this is the key to treatment.

**Schizonepeta Decoction**
*Simmer:*
- Schizonepeta (chopped, 3 bowls of water)

Use the decoction to wash the hemorrhoids.
After washing, return the liquid to a bottle and warm over fire for reuse, three to five times.

**Moistening the Intestines Pill**
*Grind equal parts of the following into powder and form into honey pills:*
- Rhubarb (wrapped in damp paper and roasted, then chopped)
- Bitter orange (peel removed)
- Chinese angelica (honey-processed)

Take 20–30 pills with warm water, adjusting dosage based on the patient’s bowel condition.
*This is administered after the caustic paste has nearly desiccated the hemorrhoid,
when the anus feels constricted and bowel movements may become difficult.
The pill ensures the intestines remain smooth and unobstructed.*

**Dragon-Stone Powder**
*Grind each into an extremely fine powder:*
- Calcined dragon bone (fire toxin removed)
- Dahurian angelica
- High-quality red lead
- Calcined gypsum (fire toxin removed)

Apply this powder after the hemorrhoid head has completely fallen off to promote wound healing.
Prepare *Blood-Coagulating Powder* in advance for emergency use to stop bleeding or close wounds.

**Guide Out the Red Powder**
*Chop and simmer:*
- Rehmannia (2 taels)
- Scutellaria (3 taels)

Take 3 candareens per dose with 1 cup of water, simmered to 60–70%.
Serve warm.
*After applying the caustic paste, if urination becomes dark and difficult,
take this with added talcum, licorice, and rush pith.*

**Double Gold Powder**
*Grind equal parts into an extremely fine powder:*
- Coptis
- Turmeric

Mix with honey water and apply to the hemorrhoid head.
*For weak patients experiencing pain after caustic paste application, use this.
An alternative formula uses borneol powder alone.*

**Internal Supplement Powder**
This formula regulates *qi* and blood, expels pus, and generates flesh.
Begin taking it as the hemorrhoid wound nears closure.
The anus will naturally retract once the wound heals and blood and *qi* harmonize.
*Grind equal parts of the following into fine powder:*
- Ginseng (2 taels)
- Astragalus (2 taels)
- Chinese angelica (2 taels)
- Platycodon (1 tael)
- Ligusticum (1 tael)
- Magnolia bark (1 tael)
- Cinnamon (1 tael)
- Saposhnikovia (1 tael)
- Dahurian angelica (1 tael)
- Licorice (1 tael)

Take two to three doses daily with costus root decoction or warm wine.

**Licorice Decoction**
Simmer licorice and use the decoction to steam and wash hemorrhoids.
Licorice is inherently a hemorrhoid remedy and also neutralizes arsenic toxicity.
If the wound itches abnormally during healing, this decoction—applied warm—is especially effective.

**Hemorrhoid Catalyst**
For hardened hemorrhoids that refuse to detach, apply this to induce shedding.
*Grind into fine powder:*
- Soot from burned herbs (2 candareens)
- White ginger powder (1 candareen)
- Sichuan aconite

Mix with well water to a thin consistency and apply to the hemorrhoid with a brush.
It will detach shortly thereafter.

**Fomentation Method**
After applying the caustic paste, if healthy tissue around the anus stings like needle pricks
or pain radiates to the kidney region during bowel movements,
have someone heat clothing or fabric over fire and apply it warm to the painful area three to five times.
The pain will cease immediately.

**Water-Settled Paste (Reiterated)**
This paste prevents toxic fluid from the hemorrhoid root from contaminating healthy tissue and causing sores.
Apply the paste to oil-treated paper, covering the entire anal circumference,
but do not extend the paper downward—secure it in place.

**Hemmorhoid-Calling Powder**
- True magnetite (separately ground): 1 candareen
- White ginger (separately ground): 1 candareen
- Calcined white alum: ½ candareen
- Raw Sichuan aconite tips: 3 pieces

Grind into powder, then mix with scallion mucus and apply to the anal protrusion. Once the hemorrhoid emerges, use the caustic paste.

**Alternative Formula**
- Magnetite (calcined, quenched in vinegar nine times, ground, water-floated)
- Calcined white alum
- Large Sichuan aconite
- Pangolin scales
- Cinnabar

Grind into powder as above; after emergence, use the washing powder.

**Song of the Twenty-Four Hemorrhoid Types**
This malady stems from excess in five matters: wine, lust, qi, wind, and diet.
The hemorrhoid types number three times eight—observe them closely, sir,
Lest time pass and the sight chill your heart and gall.
Water caltrop’s form is strange; lotus flower, unbearable to see.
Bowel-piercing and rat-teat types arise from wine and lust alike.
Do not wish for the resentful *fan-hua* or the unyielding beehive.
Male and female share the same qi and blood; mother and child coil within the bowel.
The *xuan-zhu* is eerie; the *gou-chang* drills like pain.
Walnut and *liu-qi* types move the heart to sorrow.
The *□-zi* swells large within; the chicken-heart rests without.
Coral’s shape is vile—how much worse the prolapsed anus!
Internal hemorrhoids, red but unprotruded, coil within the bowel’s fold.
The *chui-zhu* is harder still to cure; over time, it grows a cockscomb.
Never treat lightly with blade or fire, lest you endanger life.
Dedicate effort without half-measures to eradicate the disease at its root.

Use the *Hemmorhoid-Calling Powder* as described.

**Red-Flesh Paste for Hemorrhoids**
- Cinnabar: 1 candareen
- Yellow lead: 1 candareen
- Frankincense (separately ground): ½ candareen
- White alum: 1 tael
- Arsenic (placed over white alum, calcined to 70%): ½ tael
- Croton seeds: 3 pieces

Mix the oil with the powder to form a paste. Apply according to the hemorrhoid’s size, changing the dressing once every one or two days. After six or seven days, if the area turns black and charred, discontinue application and use the *Cui* powder. For unbroken or broken hemorrhoids, insert the medicine into the sore using a paper wick for best results.

**Golden Flower Powder for Washing Hemorrhoids**
- Pyrolusite: ½ candareen
- *Huang-bo*: 1 tael
- Coptis (raw): ½ tael
- Black soybeans: ½ sheng

Grind into powder. After washing with warm water, apply the *Clam Shell Powder*.

**Dragon Bone and Clam Shell Powder**
- Ulmus fruit: 1 tael
- Dragon bone (calcined): 1 candareen
- Clam shell (calcined): 1 candareen
- Litharge: ½ candareen

Grind into powder. First dust the area, then apply the *Hemorrhoid Paste* once daily.

**Frankincense Paste for Hemorrhoids**
- Evodia fruit
- Bletilla
- Ampelopsis
- Coptis
- *Huang-bo*
- Chinese angelica (equal parts)

Use 4 taels of sesame oil and 3 chi 4 cun of willow twigs. Fry the twigs in the oil until black, then add the powdered herbs and fry until the mixture turns purple. Strain through silk, then boil again several times. Add 1–2 candareens of yellow lead and frankincense, and simmer into a paste. Store in a ceramic jar. Apply a small amount to the sore for immediate effect.

For prolapsed hemorrhoids, first administer blood-moving medicine twice daily, then use the *Hemmorhoid-Calling Powder*.

- Coptis: ½ tael
- Hemp seeds: ½ tael
- Chinese angelica: ½ tael

Grind into powder. For bloody discharge, take 2 *qian* with aged rice decoction on an empty stomach.

- *Rui Sheng* (Asparagus): ½ portion
- *Guan Zhong* (Dryopteris): 1 *liang*

Grind into powder. For each dose, take 2 *qian* with musk-infused wine.

For internal hemorrhoids, first apply *Cong Xian* Paste, then use the *Intestinal-Washing Tangkuei Pill*, followed by the *Blood-Extracting Tangkuei Powder*, then the *Blood-Extracting Coptis Pill*. The next day, apply the *Red Flesh Paste*.

Avoid foods that obstruct blood and toxins when taking medicine, and do not rub or disturb the affected area to prevent wind invasion. If foul fluid oozes and corrodes healthy flesh, causing sores, apply *He Feng* Paste. To prevent interference with daily activities, apply medicine to cotton, cover the hemorrhoids, and secure with cloth, twice daily. For severe cases, apply for ten days; for mild cases, eight days.

If hemorrhoids connect to the intestines and cause stagnation with lumbar pain, apply *Rou Gui* Paste to the lower back. For vexing pain, take *Tong Xin Powder* daily, followed by *Ding Ge Powder*, *Wei Jiang Pill*, and *Zhi Qiao Powder*. After the hemorrhoids fall, wash with *Hai Ge Powder* and apply *Ru Xiang Paste*. Use the *Pus-Absorbing Paste* for three days, then wash with medicine for three days. Sprinkle *Long Gu Hai Ge Powder* and *Che Qian Powder* into the wound opening twice daily. Take medicine for three doses until deep efficacy is achieved. If fluid oozes afterward, the treatment is effective.

- Arsenic: ½ *qian*
- *Yi Yao* (Medicinal Mineral): ½ *qian*
- Frankincense: ½ *qian*
- Alum: 1 *liang*
- Mirabilite: 1 *liang*

Place in a silver or stone vessel, add rice vinegar to a depth of one finger, and decoct until dry. Remove the croton, dry-fry, and grind into powder. Form into pills with vinegar paste. For each dose, take fifteen pills with tea on an empty stomach, or swallow with saliva.

For intestinal wind with bloody discharge, decoct *Ping Wei Powder* with *Xu Duan* (Dipsacus) and take. Another formula adds forty-nine wheat grains and omits *Xu Duan*.

For hemorrhoid sores, use equal parts wax and lotus seedpod, slowly fumigate over low heat until slightly smoking.

For bloody discharge from scalding wind, take 2 *qian* of *Wu Bei Zi* powder with musk-infused wine.

**Hemorrhoid Treatment**
- Alum: 4 *liang*
- Green vitriol: 1 portion
- Arsenic: ½ *liang*
- Mirabilite: ½ *liang*

Burn with approximately two *jin* of charcoal from all sides until bubbling. When dry, grind into fine powder and store in a sand jar. Next, wash with hot *Mao Gen* (Imperata) decoction, then apply the medicine, changing it three to five times day and night.

When hemorrhoids flare, the large intestine is often constipated. Take *Kuan Chang Pill* and *Tong Da Bian* (bowel-moving medicine) to relax the bowels. Do not fumigate with smoke, as it may enter the intestines and cause harm.

In summer, add *Bai Cao Shuang* (Soot) and *Huang Dan* (Lead Oxide) to the application.

After hemorrhoids fall, if the anus is swollen and painful, wash with a decoction of sophora bark, or apply *Zhi Qiao* (Aurantium) ground on a tile with saliva. Before the hemorrhoids fall, decoct *Huang Pi* (Phellodendron bark) and mint, mix with saliva, and apply to the anus. This is especially effective in summer.

**Initial Washing Formula**
- *Mu Tong* (Akebia)
- *Huang Qin* (Scutellaria)
- *Huang Bai* (Phellodendron)

Decoct while hot and wash three times.

chunks.translated_text:
**Volume Ten of *Emergency Divine Formulas*
*Shangqing Ziting Pursuit of Consumption: Immortal Methods and Discourse***

**Preface by an Old Recluse**
This text has circulated for generations, yet its author’s name remains unknown. Only this writing survives; I dare not presumptuously add to it, awaiting those who may recognize its origins.

Since my entry into the world, I have devoted myself to the study of medicinal arts, swiftly aiding those in peril. Acupuncture and moxibustion, the *Mingtang* charts—I have examined all in detail. Searching texts and consulting records, I discern the flourishing and decline of the five viscera. Reflecting on the ancients, I find their wisdom remains unfathomed by the age.

Consider: Why did Duke Jing of Jin die? Why was the Crown Prince of Guo revived? I ponder the feats of scraping bone and reconnecting sinew, of opening the intestines to remove disease—yet none is as inscrutable as the ailment of *transmitted corpse-consumption*. Though it arises within a single body, its transformations are myriad.

For physicians, to clarify pulse signs and trace the root of illness is not inherently difficult. Yet a hairsbreadth’s error leads to a thousand *li*’s deviation.

**On Transmitted Consumption**
*Transmitted corpse-consumption* stems from the *Three Corpse Demons* and the *Nine Worms*, whose calamities are fully expounded here to enlighten the uninitiated.

**General Discourse on Transmitted Consumption**
*Transmitted corpse-consumption* originates in the heart, where qi congeals and blood coagulates, giving rise to worms. This arises from indulgence in drink, lust, sorrow, and the dissipation of essence. Worms become *gu* parasites, nourished by stagnant blood and qi. When qi and blood reside in the womb, they constitute *orthodox qi*; when they lodge in the qi, they form emaciating masses; when they congeal in the heart, they become worms. All this stems from a heart not aligned with the Dao, entangled in the karmic web of sorrow.

The harms of the *Three Corpses* and *Nine Worms* must be known in detail by those who treat this affliction. Among the *Nine Worms*, six are transmitted across six generations, while three—*wei* (hedgehog), *hui* (roundworm), and *cunbai* (tapeworm)—are not transmitted. Of the six, some arise from inherited toxins, others from familial contagion.

At the disease’s onset, the spirit becomes disoriented, qi and pulse grow erratic. Strict abstinence from wine and lust, along with regulated diet, is imperative. Without this, the five centers grow restless, night sweats drench the heart and kidneys, and palpitations arise. Within ten days, the bones waste away, the complexion turns sallow yet lustrous—such are its signs.

Misguided faith in false masters, prayers for blessings, and the ministrations of mediocre physicians only prolong the suffering. When the illness worsens, only through vigilant restraint can fortune be grasped—else calamity follows as swiftly as the turning of a hand.

chunks.original_text: 此人死后，兄弟子孙，骨肉亲属，绵绵相传，以至臧族。 大抵六虫，一旬之中，遍行四穴，周而复始。 病经遇木气而生，立春一日后方食，起三日一食，五日一退。 方其作苦，百体有痛，虫之食也，退即还穴醉睡，一醉五日，其病乍静。 俟其退醉之时，方可投符用药，不然虫熟於符药之后，不能治也。 一虫在身中，游十二穴，六虫共占七十二穴。 一月之中，上十日虫头向上，从心至头游四穴； 中十日虫头向内，从心至脐游四穴； 下十日虫头向下，从脐至足游四穴。 若投符用药，可知如紫蚕苗在汗中。 盖虫性已通灵，切在精审。 其或取虫不补，即学浅妄行，徒费赀财，终无去病之理，可不悲哉。 师日：治传尸痨者，先须知正气与毒气并行，故脏腑有凝，即成虫状，遇阳日长雄，阴日长雌。 其食先脏腑脂膏，故其色白，五脏六腑一经食损，即皮聚毛脱，妇人即月信不行，血脉皆损，不能荣五脏六腑也。 七十日后食人血肉尽，故其虫黄赤。 损於肌肉，故变瘦劣，饮食不能为肤，筋缓不能收持。 一百二十日外，肉血食尽故其虫紫，即食精髓。 传於肾中食精，故其虫色黑，食髓即骨痿不能起於床枕。 诸虫久即生毛，毛色杂花，锺孕五脏五行之气，传之三人，即自能飞。 其状如禽，亦多品类，传入肾经，不可救治。 法之所载者，能利后其虫色白，可三十日服药补。 其虫黄赤，可六十日服药补。 其虫紫黑，此疾已极，可百二十日服药补。 又云：虫头赤者，食患人肉可治。 头口白者，食患人髓，其病难治，只宜断后，故经日：六十日者，十得七八； 八十日内治者，十得三四。 过此以往，未知生全，但可为子孙除害耳。

Upon this person’s death, the affliction passes to brothers, sons, grandsons, and all blood kin, transmitting endlessly until the clan is extinguished.

Generally, the six worms traverse the four cavities within ten days, cycling without cease. The disease takes hold when it encounters the qi of Wood; after the first day of the solar term *Lichun*, the worms begin to feed, consuming once every three days and retreating once every five. As they gnaw, the entire body aches—this is the worms feeding. When they retreat, they return to their cavities and fall into a drunken slumber, sleeping for five days, during which the illness briefly subsides. Only at the moment of their drunken retreat may talismans and medicines be administered; if the worms mature after the talismans and medicines take effect, the treatment will fail.

A single worm roams through twelve cavities; the six worms together occupy seventy-two. In the course of a month: during the first ten days, the worms’ heads point upward, traversing four cavities from the heart to the head; in the middle ten days, their heads turn inward, traversing four cavities from the heart to the navel; in the last ten days, their heads point downward, traversing four cavities from the navel to the feet. When administering talismans or medicines, one must discern their movements as precisely as silkworm larvae in cocoons. For the worms’ nature has already attained spiritual awareness—utmost care is required. If the worms are extracted without replenishment, or if the practitioner is shallow and reckless, resources will be squandered in vain, and the disease will never be eradicated. How tragic this is!

The Master says: To treat *chuanshi lao* (consumptive wasting), one must first understand that the upright qi and the toxic qi move together, so when the viscera congeal, they form worm-like shapes. On yang days, the male worms grow; on yin days, the female worms grow. They first consume the fat and marrow of the viscera, which is why their color is white. Once the five viscera and six bowels are damaged by feeding, the skin shrivels, the hair falls out, and in women, menstruation ceases as the blood vessels are depleted, unable to nourish the five viscera and six bowels. After seventy days, the worms devour all the patient’s flesh and blood, turning yellow-red. As the muscles waste, the body grows emaciated and weak, food no longer sustains the skin, and the sinews slacken, unable to support movement. After one hundred twenty days, when flesh and blood are exhausted, the worms turn purple, then consume the essence and marrow. When they transmit to the kidneys and feed on essence, the worms turn black, and the marrow is devoured, causing the bones to wither so the patient cannot rise from bed. Over time, the worms grow fur, their coats a motley of colors, imbued with the qi of the five viscera and the five phases. After passing through three hosts, they gain the ability to fly, taking forms like birds, with many varieties. Once they enter the kidney meridian, the condition becomes incurable.

The methods recorded state: If the worms are still white, the patient may take medicine to replenish for thirty days. If the worms are yellow-red, replenishment may continue for sixty days. If the worms are purple-black, the disease has reached its extreme, and replenishment must persist for one hundred twenty days. It is also said: If the worm’s head is red, it feeds on the patient’s flesh and may be treated. If its head and mouth are white, it feeds on the patient’s marrow, and the disease is difficult to cure—only measures to sever its transmission to descendants should be taken. Thus, the classics say: If treated within sixty days, seven or eight out of ten may recover; if treated within eighty days, only three or four out of ten. Beyond this, survival is uncertain, and the best one can do is spare future generations from harm.

Now, the symptoms and manifestations of the worms transmitted through six generations are detailed below.

**First Generation: Worm Manifestations, Disease Signs, and Daily Treatment Methods**
This marks the onset of consumptive disease, referring to the initial contraction of the illness, where the source remains undetected. The patient continues with wine and rich food, gradually becoming emaciated. Delay in treatment allows the disease to worsen. Physicians, failing to discern the cause, often prescribe mistaken remedies, leading to many deaths.

All the aforementioned worms, once settled within the human body, vary in size. They cause the patient to experience disordered dreams, with the hun and po spirits scattering, the spirit dispersing, and the appetite declining. The complexion gradually wastes away, the limbs grow sore and aching, the joints weary, and alternating chills and fevers arise. The back and shoulders become tense, the head and brain ache, the mouth turns bitter and the tongue dry. The face loses its color, clear snivel flows from the nose, profuse sweating occurs, walking becomes laborious, and the eyes often pain.

On bing and ding days, the worms feed, become intoxicated, and return to the *Xinshu* acupoint. They circulate through the four transport points in an endless cycle. Only when the worms are thoroughly drunk may treatment proceed. After moxibustion to extract the worms, the patient should take medicine to replenish the heart and guard the spirit with *Shouling San*.

**Second Generation: Awakened Consumptive Disease**
This refers to the transmission of the disease, where the patient becomes aware of the affliction. At night, inauspicious dreams occur, and the patient finds themselves in the company of the deceased. Upon waking, all vitality is gone, and the mind remains in a stupor, as if drunk, with the spirit unsettled. Whatever is eaten turns to harm. Qi and phlegm may stir, or wind-toxin may assail, causing disharmony in the limbs, fullness and oppression in the chest, and gradual emaciation. The bones and joints wither, sour water may be vomited, or the stomach may burn with acidity. The lips grow parched, the mouth bitter, the nose congested, and the chest pained. The back and shoulders ache, profuse sweating occurs, and the waist and knees throb with pain.

Such symptoms demand early treatment; delay makes cure difficult and risks fatality.

All the aforementioned worms, once within the body, cause the patient to gasp for breath, the lips and mouth to dry, coughing and chills to worsen, and the heart to feel vexed and congested. The hair withers and falls, qi swells, and sourness is swallowed. Body fluids gradually deplete, leading to frequent thirst. Clear fluid flows from the nose, the limbs weaken, the face reddens while the complexion yellows, and the skin grows withered. The waist and knees lose strength, the spine aches, blood is spat or pus coughed up, speech becomes impaired, the nose clogs, and the head pains. The chest fills with phlegm.

In severe cases, the heart feels stifled, blood is vomited, and the patient may collapse to the ground, unaware of their surroundings.

On geng and xin days, the worms feed, become intoxicated, and return to the *Feishu* acupoint. They circulate through the four transport points in an endless cycle. Only when the worms are thoroughly drunk may treatment proceed. After extracting the worms, replenishing the lungs will restore depleted qi.

**Third Generation: Transmitted Corpse Consumptive Disease**
This refers to the transmission of the disease, where the patient gradually becomes aware of it, growing thinner by the day and altering in appearance. Each day brings distress, each night the fear of death. Without encountering a skilled physician, death draws near.

All the aforementioned worms, once within the body, cause the *sanjiao* to grow muddled, inducing constant drowsiness. Bitter juice or clear water may be vomited, sometimes sweet, sometimes bitter, with sticky phlegm often congesting. The abdomen swells and rumbles, and after lying down, the patient startles easily. Sores appear in the mouth and nose, the lips darken, the face turns sallow, and emaciation progresses. The spirit becomes distracted, the hun and po scatter, food is not digested, the voice grows hoarse, and the eyes often blur with tears.

chunks.original_text: 此虫形如猪肺在人腹中 此虫形如蛇虺在人五脏中 已上诸虫，在人身中，令人脏腑虚呜，呕逆伤中，癖气块，增寒壮热，肚大筋生，腰背疼痛，或虚或瘦，泻利无时，行履困重，四肢憔悴，上急气喘，口苦舌乾，饮食及水过多，要吃酸咸之 物。 其虫遇戊己日，食起醉归脾俞穴中，四肢轮转，周而复始，俟虫大醉方可治，取出虫后，补脾为瘥魂停。 第五代 此虫形如鼠似小瓶浑无表里背面 此虫形如有头无足有足无头 此虫形变动形如精血斤在於阳宫 已上诸虫，入肝经而归肾，得血而变更也，令人多怒气逆，筋骨拳挛，四肢解散，唇黑面青，增寒壮热，腰背疼痛，起坐无力，头如斧斫，眼睛时痛，翳膜多泪，背膊刺痛，力乏虚羸，手足乾枯，卧着床枕，不能起止，有似风中，肢体顽麻，腹内多痛，眼见黑花，忽然倒地，不省人事，梦寐不祥，觉来遍体虚汗，或有面色红润如平时者，或有通灵而言未来事者。 其虫遇癸未日，食起醉归肝俞穴中，四穴轮转，周而复始，俟虫大醉，方可医救，取虫出后，补肝乃得瘥金明。 第六代 此代虫有翅足全者，千里传疰所谓飞尸，不以常法治也。 此虫形如马尾有两条一雌一雄 此虫形如龟鳖在人五脏中 此虫形如烂面或长或短或如飞禽 已上诸虫，在人身中，居於肾脏，透连脊骨，令人思食，百物要吃，身体尪羸腰膝无力，髓寒骨热，四体乾枯，眼见火生，或多黑暗，耳内虚鸣，阴汗燥痒，冷汗如油，梦多鬼交，小便黄赤，醒后昏沉，脐下结硬，或奔心胸，看物如艳，心腹闷乱，骨节疼痛，食物进退，有时喘嗽。 其虫遇丑亥日，食起醉归肾俞穴中，四穴轮转，周而复始，俟虫 大醉可医治，取虫后，补肾填精瘥育婴散。 苏游论 论日：大抵传尸之候在心，胸胁满闷，背膊烦痛，两目不明，四肢无力，虽欲寝卧，睡常不寐，脊膂急痛，腰膝酸疼，多卧少起，状如佯病，每至早旦，精神尚存，有如无病，日午之后，四体微热，面无颜色，喜见人过，常怀忿怒，才不称意，即多嗔恚，行立脚弱，夜卧盗汗，梦与鬼交，或见先亡，或多惊怖，有时气息，有时咳嗽，虽思饮食，不能多餐，死在须臾。 精神尚好，或时微利，两胁虚胀，口燥鼻乾，常多粘唾，有时唇赤，有时欲睡，渐就沉羸，犹如涸鱼不觉死也。 又曰：传尸之候，本起无端，莫问老少，男女皆有此疾。 大抵五行相克，而生穴内，传毒气周遍五脏，渐熟羸瘦，以至于死，死讫又传家亲一人，故曰传尸，亦名传疰。 以其初传，半卧半起； 号日掩殜。

These worms resemble pig lungs within the human abdomen. These worms resemble snakes and vipers within the five viscera. All the aforementioned worms, dwelling in the human body, cause the viscera and bowels to rumble with vacuity, counterflow vomiting that damages the center, accumulations and gatherings of *qi* masses, alternating chills and high fever, abdominal distension with visible veins, lumbar and dorsal pain, emaciation or vacuity, unregulated diarrhea, difficulty in walking, and emaciation of the four limbs. The patient suffers from upper urgency with panting, a bitter taste in the mouth, dry tongue, and excessive intake of food and water, craving sour and salty flavors.

On *wu* and *ji* days, the worms feed, become intoxicated, and return to the *Pishu* acupoint. They circulate through the four transport points in an endless cycle. Only when the worms are thoroughly drunk may treatment proceed. After extracting the worms, replenishing the spleen will effect a cure, stabilizing the *hun* and settling the spirit.

**Fifth Generation**
These worms resemble mice or small jars, lacking distinct exterior and interior, front and back. These worms may have heads without feet or feet without heads. These worms transform and shift, resembling *jin* of essence-blood within the Yang Palace.

All the aforementioned worms enter the Liver Channel and return to the Kidneys, transforming upon encountering blood. They cause frequent anger and counterflow *qi*, spasms and contractions of sinews and bones, dissolution of the four limbs, darkened lips and sallow complexion, alternating chills and high fever, lumbar and dorsal pain, weakness when rising or sitting, a sensation of the head being cleaved by an axe, intermittent eye pain, nebulae and excessive tearing, stabbing pain in the shoulders and back, fatigue and emaciation, desiccation of the hands and feet, and inability to rise from bed. The condition resembles wind-stroke, with numbness of the limbs, frequent abdominal pain, visualizing black flowers, sudden collapse, loss of consciousness, inauspicious dreams, and profuse sweating upon waking. Some patients may appear ruddy and healthy as usual, while others may exhibit clairvoyance, foretelling future events.

On *gui* and *wei* days, the worms feed, become intoxicated, and return to the *Ganshu* acupoint. They circulate through the four transport points in an endless cycle. Only when the worms are thoroughly drunk may treatment proceed. After extracting the worms, replenishing the liver will effect a cure, restoring clarity and brilliance.

**Sixth Generation**
Some of these worms possess complete wings and legs, capable of transmitting *zhu* over a thousand *li*—so-called "flying corpse"—and cannot be treated by conventional methods.

These worms resemble horse tails, existing in pairs, one male and one female. These worms resemble tortoises and turtles within the five viscera. These worms resemble rotted dough, varying in length or resembling flying birds.

All the aforementioned worms reside in the human body within the Kidney Viscus, penetrating and connecting to the spinal bones. They induce cravings for all manner of food, emaciation, weakness of the waist and knees, cold marrow and feverish bones, desiccation of the four limbs, visualizing sparks or darkness, vacuous ringing in the ears, itching and dampness of the genitals, oily cold sweats, frequent dreams of ghostly intercourse, dark yellow urine, post-sleep stupor, hardness below the navel, or rushing upward to the heart and chest. Objects appear vividly colored, the heart and abdomen feel stifled and chaotic, the joints ache, and food intake fluctuates, sometimes accompanied by panting and coughing.

On *chou* and *hai* days, the worms feed, become intoxicated, and return to the *Shenshu* acupoint. They circulate through the four transport points in an endless cycle. Only when the worms are thoroughly drunk may treatment proceed. After extracting the worms, replenishing the kidneys and filling the essence will effect a cure, dispersing the *Yuying* affliction.

**Su You’s Treatise**
The Master states: Generally, the signs of *chuanshi* disease manifest in the heart, with fullness and oppression in the chest and flanks, vexing pain in the shoulders and back, dimness of the eyes, weakness of the four limbs, and a desire to lie down, though sleep remains elusive. The spine and ribs ache sharply, the waist and knees feel sore, and the patient lies abed most of the time, rising little, appearing feigned in illness. At dawn, the spirit may yet seem intact, as if no illness were present, but by midday, the four limbs grow slightly feverish, the complexion fades, and the patient takes pleasure in visitors, harboring frequent resentment. The slightest dissatisfaction provokes anger, and standing or walking causes leg weakness. At night, the patient sweats stealthily, dreams of ghostly intercourse, or sees the departed, often experiencing fright. At times, the breath feels stifled, or coughing arises. Though craving food, the patient cannot eat much, and death may come in an instant.

The spirit may still seem sound, or there may be slight diarrhea, vacuous distension of the flanks, dry mouth and nose, frequent sticky saliva, intermittent reddening of the lips, or a desire to sleep. Gradually, the patient grows emaciated, like a fish in a dried-up pond, unaware of impending death.

It is further said: The signs of *chuanshi* arise without cause, afflicting the old and young, men and women alike. Generally, the five phases contend and generate within the acupoints, transmitting toxic *qi* throughout the five viscera, leading to gradual emaciation and death. Upon death, the affliction passes to a family member, hence the name *chuanshi* ("transmitted corpse") or *chuanzhu* ("transmitted *zhu*"). As the disease first transmits, the patient alternates between lying down and rising—thus it is also called *yandie* ("concealed burial").

chunks.original_text: 气息嗽者，名日肺痿痎。 骨体身中热，称为骨蒸。 内传五脏，名曰复连，不解疗者，乃至灭门。 假如男女虚损得之，名日劳极。 吴楚乃名淋沥。 巴蜀亦名劳极。 其源先从肾起，初受之气，两经酸疼，腰背拘急，行立脚弱，饮食咸#1少，两耳飕飕，真似风声，夜卧遗泄，阴汗痿弱。 肾既受讫，次传於心。 心初受气，夜卧心惊，或多恐悸，心悬之气，吸吸欲尽，梦见传於先亡，有时盗汗，饮食无味，口内生疮，心气烦热，惟欲眠卧，朝轻夕重，两颊口唇，悉皆纹赤，如傅胭脂，又时手足五心烦热。 心受已，次传於肺。 肺初受气，咳嗽，气力微痛，有时喘气，外即便甚，鼻口乾燥，不闻香臭，如或忽闻，惟觉枯腐物气，有时恶心，愦愦欲吐，肌肤枯燥，时或疼痛，或似虫行，乾皮细起，状若麸片。 肺既受已，次传於肝。 肝初受气，两目胱胱，面无血色，尚欲颦眉，眼视不远，目常乾涩，又时赤痛，或复睛黄，朝昏懵蓦，常欲合眼，及时睡外，常睡不着。 肝既受已，次传於脾。 脾初受气，两肋虚胀，食不消化，又时泻利，水谷生虫，有时肚痛，腹胀雷呜，唇口焦乾，或生疮肿，毛发乾耸，无有光润，或时上气，撑肩喘息，痢赤黑汁，见此证者，乃不治也。 夫骨蒸、殗殜、复连、尸疰、痨疰、虫疰、毒疰、热疰、玲疰、食疰、鬼疰等，皆曰传尸者。 以疰者注也，病自上注也。 与人相似，故曰疰。 其变有二十二种，或三十六种，或九十九种，大略令人寒热盗汗，梦与鬼交，遗精白浊，发乾而耸，或腹内有块，或脑后两边有小结，复连数个，或聚或散，沈沈默默，咳嗽痰涎，或咯#2脓血，如肺痿肺痈状，或复下痢，羸瘦困乏，不自胜持，积月累年，以至于死，死复传疰，易传亲人，乃至灭门者是也。 更有蜚虫、遁尸、寒尸、丧尸、尸疰等，谓之五尸，及大小附疰等证，不的知其所苦，无处不恶，乃挟诸鬼邪而害人。 其证多端，传变推迁，难以推测，故自古及今，愈此病者十不一得。 所谓狸骨、獭肝、天灵盖、铜锁鼻，徒有其说，未尝取效，惟膏肓俞崔氏穴法，若闻早灸之，可否几半，晚亦不济也。 痨疗诸证 病者增寒壮热，自汗面白，目乾口苦，精神不守，恐畏不能独外，其传在肝。 病者寒热，面黑鼻燥，忽忽喜忘，大便苦难，或复清泻，口疮，其传在心。 病者增寒发热，面青唇黄，舌举强不能，饮食无味，四肢羸瘦，口吐涎沫，其传在脾。 病者增寒发热，面赤鼻乾，口燥毛折，咯嗽喘急，时吐白涎，或有血线，其传在肺。 病者增寒增热，面黄，耳轮焦枯，腑骨损痛，小便血浊，遗沥，其传在肾。 所谓痨蒸者，二十四种，随证皆可考。 若眉毛折，发焦，肌肤甲错，其蒸在脾。 外人觉热，自返思寒，身振鹏剧，其蒸在肉。 发焦鼻衄，或复尿血，其蒸在血。 方热烦燥，痛如刺针，其蒸在脉。 爪甲焦枯，目昏，两胁急痛，其蒸在筋，版杼齿黑痛燥，大杼醉痛，其蒸在骨。 背膂疼痛，胻骨酸□，其蒸在脑。 男子失精，女人自淫，其蒸在玉房。 乍寒乍热，中腕目肿，中烦闷，其蒸在三焦。 小便黄赤，凝浊如膏，其蒸在膀胱。 传道不均，或泄或秘，腹中雷呜，其蒸在小肠。 大腹隐隐，右鼻乾疼，其蒸在大肠。
chunks.translated_text:
Those with wheezing breath are called *feiwei jie*. Heat within the bones and body is termed *guzheng* ("bone steaming"). When it transmits internally to the five viscera, it is called *fulian* ("recurring link"). If left untreated, it may extinguish an entire household.

For instance, when men or women with vacuity detriment contract this, it is called *laoji* ("exhaustion extremity"). In Wu and Chu, it is named *linli* ("dripping"). In Ba and Shu, it is also called *laoji*. Its origin first arises from the kidneys. Upon initially receiving the *qi*, both channels ache, the waist and back become tense and stiff, the legs weaken when walking or standing, salty foods are consumed sparingly, both ears ring with a sound like wind, and at night, there is seminal emission, yin sweating, and impotence.

Once the kidneys have received it, it next transmits to the heart. When the heart first receives the *qi*, the patient experiences nighttime fright, frequent terror and palpitations, a suspended heart *qi* that seems on the verge of exhaustion, dreams of transmission from the deceased, occasional night sweats, tasteless food, sores in the mouth, vexing heat in the heart *qi*, a constant desire to sleep, worsening symptoms at dusk, and both cheeks, lips, and mouth turning red as if rouged. The palms and soles also frequently burn with heat.

After the heart has received it, it next transmits to the lungs. When the lungs first receive the *qi*, there is coughing, slight pain in the *qi* force, occasional panting, immediate external worsening, dryness of the nose and mouth, an inability to smell fragrance or stench—if suddenly detected, only the scent of decay is perceived—occasional nausea, confusion, and retching. The skin becomes parched, sometimes painful, or as if insects crawl beneath it, with dry flakes peeling like wheat bran.

Once the lungs have received it, it next transmits to the liver. When the liver first receives the *qi*, both eyes dim, the face loses its color, the patient furrows their brow, vision blurs, the eyes are often dry and sore, sometimes red or yellow, and there is confusion at dawn and dusk, a constant desire to close the eyes, yet difficulty sleeping when lying down.

After the liver has received it, it next transmits to the spleen. When the spleen first receives the *qi*, both flanks become vacuously distended, food is not digested, there is occasional diarrhea, worms breed in the undigested food, the abdomen sometimes aches, the belly swells with rumbling, the lips and mouth become parched and cracked, or sores and swellings appear. The hair dries and stands on end, losing its luster. Occasionally, there is counterflow *qi*, shoulder heaving, and panting. If dysentery with red or black pus appears, the condition is incurable.

Now, *guzheng*, *niedie*, *fulian*, *shizhu*, *laozhu*, *chongzhu*, *duzhu*, *rezhu*, *lingzhu*, *shizhu*, and *guizhu* are all called *chuanshi* ("transmitted corpse"). The term *zhu* means "to pour"—the disease pours downward from above. It resembles others, hence the name *zhu*. Its transformations number twenty-two, thirty-six, or ninety-nine kinds. Generally, it causes alternating cold and heat, night sweats, dreams of intercourse with ghosts, seminal emission and white turbidity, dry and brittle hair, or lumps in the abdomen, or small nodules on both sides behind the nape, linked in clusters that gather and disperse. The patient grows silent and withdrawn, coughs up phlegm and saliva, or spits pus and blood like *feiwei* or *feiyong*, or suffers from diarrhea, emaciation, and exhaustion, unable to endure. Over months and years, it leads to death, and after death, the affliction transmits again, easily passing to kin, even extinguishing entire households.

Other conditions like *feichong* ("flying worms"), *dunshi* ("concealed corpse"), *hanshi* ("cold corpse"), *sangshi* ("mourning corpse"), *shizhu* ("corpse *zhu*"), and the five *shi*, as well as major and minor *fuzhu*, cause suffering in unknown locations, with no place untouched, as if possessed by ghostly malignities. Their symptoms are manifold, their transmissions and changes unpredictable, making them difficult to diagnose. Thus, from ancient times to the present, scarcely one in ten recovers. Remedies like fox bones, otter liver, *tianlinggai*, or copper nose locks exist in name only, never proven effective. Only the *gaohuang* transport point and Master Cui’s needling method offer hope—if moxibustion is applied early, recovery may be half possible, but late treatment is futile.

**Symptoms of Consumptive Ailments**

When the patient experiences alternating cold and high fever, spontaneous sweating, a pale face, dry eyes and bitter mouth, ungrounded spirit, and fear of being alone outside, the transmission is in the liver.

When the patient has alternating cold and heat, a dark face and dry nose, sudden forgetfulness, difficult bowel movements or clear diarrhea, and mouth sores, the transmission is in the heart.

When the patient suffers alternating cold and fever, a greenish face and yellow lips, a stiff tongue unable to move, tasteless food, emaciated limbs, and foamy saliva, the transmission is in the spleen.

When the patient has alternating cold and fever, a red face and dry nose, parched mouth and brittle hair, coughing, panting, and urgent breathing, with occasional white phlegm or streaks of blood, the transmission is in the lungs.

When the patient experiences alternating cold and heat, a yellow face, withered and dry ear rims, aching lumbar bones, bloody and turbid urine, and dribbling, the transmission is in the kidneys.

**The Twenty-Four Kinds of Consumptive Steaming**

If the eyebrows break, the hair withers, and the skin becomes scaly, the steaming is in the spleen.

If others feel heat while the patient feels cold, and the body trembles violently, the steaming is in the flesh.

If the hair withers, the nose bleeds, or there is bloody urine, the steaming is in the blood.

If there is feverish vexation and pain like needle pricks, the steaming is in the vessels.

If the nails wither, the eyes dim, and both flanks ache sharply, the steaming is in the sinews.

If the teeth blacken, ache, and dry, and the *dazhu* point is painful, the steaming is in the bones.

If the spine aches, the shin bones sour and [lacuna], the steaming is in the brain.

If men lose essence and women experience spontaneous arousal, the steaming is in the Jade Chamber.

If there is sudden cold and heat, swelling in the central chest and eyes, and internal vexation, the steaming is in the Triple Burner.

If the urine is yellow and red, thick and turbid like paste, the steaming is in the bladder.

If the transmission is uneven, with either diarrhea or constipation, and rumbling in the abdomen, the steaming is in the small intestine.

If the abdomen subtly aches and the right nostril is dry and sore, the steaming is in the large intestine.
